pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [7a372e29f1](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17787/commits/7a372e29f1ce91e201cba7ed2b90d1146908b597)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.ApproximateUnit`|735|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Filter.IsApproximateUnit`
`+ iff_le_nhds_one`
`+ iff_neBot_and_le_nhds_one`
`+ mono`
`+ nhds_one`
`+ pure_one`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
sorry about those docstrings, I have no idea how I missed that.
(Coming for the last look in 10 minutes)

:v: j-loreaux can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11744567818/job/32719978955)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11744567818/job/32719979388)

Thanks!

bors d+
Looks good! I'll let Anatole have a last look but I'm happy with this.
Looks good! I'll let Anatole have a last look but I'm happy with this.

Thanks!

bors d+

```suggestion
@[to_additive "The largest filter `l` such that `Tendsto (· + m) l (𝓝 m)` and
`Tendsto (m + ·) l (𝓝 m)`"]
```

```suggestion
tends to `m` along the filter generated by the basis. In the case of normed rings, it is often
required that the elements of the basis are contained in the unit ball. In order to reduce the
```
There's some sort of sentence fragment after the period, I'm not sure exactly what you wanted to say here.
rather than taking what?
Why not define a predicate on `Filter`s instead? You can ask for 2 `Tendsto`s and `Disjoint l (cobounded α)`.

Ah, that's a nice approach. I didn't think of the `Disjoint` spelling, and I'm also looking ahead to C*-algebras, where you really do want a basis with certain properties.

But for this definition I'll make the change to go basis-free.
I don't understand why we would need a basis for this. Can't we just say that `l ≤ principal (Metric.ball 0 1)`?

~~Indeed you can there. I updated this to stop beating around the bush and just focus on the case I have in mind, which is obviously C⋆-algebras. I think the claim probably holds in other settings too (e.g., for approximate units in the convolution algebra $$L^1(\mathbb{R})$$).~~

I think this is garbage. Filters are fine without the bases. I got myself tied in knots. Anatole helped me untangle myself.

Do you have a reference for this assumption ? Naively it feels a bit out of place (as in, we're going to introduce a stronger assumption in the normed setting anyway), but I'm guessing this has something to do with matrices not having a norm ?

No, it's not about matrices (they don't have a bornology either). It was more just that when I went reading, it seemed that unbounded approximate identities were quite pathological (e.g., see [here](https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/43C36850709EE1DF6E22AC965C11722F/S0017089500008703a.pdf/unbounded-approximate-identities-in-normed-algebras.pdf), although I think I had found even more convincing evidence before, but I don't recall what it was).

However, I'm not committed to keeping this condition if we think it's better to remove it.
Perhaps we could remove the condition for now, and add it back later if not having it ends up being annoying.
I've removed it, but if we prefer to put it back (even in this PR) it's just a `git revert` away.

Indeed my thinking was not that we should try to work hard to include unbounded approximate identities (they seem pathological intuitively, and I'm glad I now know more precisely what goes wrong). My thinking was that you were going to introduce a more specific "supported on the closed unit ball" class for normed algebras anyway in #18506 (this is the general definition Bourbaki uses in a general normed algebra). Now, I don't know why I thought that because that's not what #18506 is. More interestingly, I don't know (let's say in normed algebras) wether there is any crucial distinction between "bounded approximate units" and "approximate units in the closed unit ball", the distinction being that we can talk about the former but not the latter if we just have a bornology.

So really I still don't know what is the right thing to do here. I think by default I would prefer to not add the condition until we're sure it's not going to backfire (e.g if someone wants to write down an approximate unit in the algebra of compactly supported smooth functions and convolution, I don't want them to have to define a bornology and everything if not necessary), but if at any points that causes trouble I'm completely fine with adding it back.

Note: adding the bornology to matrices would be perfectly fine, since it's completely canonical

> Now, I don't know why I thought that because that's not what #18506 is.

Well, it *does* include that `IncreasingApproximateUnit`, but that also has the condition that the elements are nonnegative, so there is a potential in-between predicate here.

> any crucial distinction between "bounded approximate units" and "approximate units in the closed unit ball"

This distinction matters for C⋆-algebras in the context of `IncreasingApproximateUnit`s, because the point is that if `0 ≤ x` and `‖x‖ ≤ 1`, then `0 ≤ 1 - x`, which is used *everywhere*.

> Note: adding the bornology to matrices would be perfectly fine, since it's completely canonical

Of course, but we don't have it at the moment I don't think.

```suggestion
structure Filter.IsApproximateUnit {α : Type*} [TopologicalSpace α] [Mul α]
    (l : Filter α) where
```
As per [Kyle's message here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/113488-general/topic/v4.2E14.2E0-rc2.20discussion/near/481022566) this is no longer needed in Lean 4.14.
that's nice, but I'd prefer to leave it there for clarity.
This is still true (and slightly stronger) if you replace `closedBall` by `ball` right? Anyway, we can talk about this in the following PR.

It's still true, but not *stronger*, it's *weaker*, since `{x | a ≤ x} ∩ ball 0 1 ⊆ {x | a ≤ x} ∩ closedBall 0 1`. Note that it's the convergence which is the hard thing to prove, not the fact that it's not `⊥`.

```suggestion
/-- If `l` is an approximate unit and `⊥ < l' ≤ l`, then `l'` is also an approximate unit. -/
lemma mono {l l' : Filter α} (hl : l.IsApproximateUnit) (hle : l' ≤ l) [l'.NeBot] :
```
(I don't feel strongly about the name, but this is what I would have expected)

```suggestion
lemma _root_.Filter.isApproximateUnit_iff_le_nhds_one [ContinuousMul α] {l : Filter α} :
```
I would say that it's okay to remove the "neBot" part from the lemma name. 

Also, even though it's slightly weaker, did you consider moving `NeBot` in the assumptions, like for [cauchy_iff_le](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/UniformSpace/Cauchy.html#cauchy_iff_le)? I'm not fully convinced myself, but if that sounds like a good idea to you I'd say go for it.

I kept the name and added the version which assumes `NeBot` under the name you suggested (well, almost, I kept it inside the namespace; I realize dot notation doesn't apply, but I think it's better to namespace more things).

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: define `Filter.IsApproximateUnit` and basic API
